image.altText: Hundreds of pelicans are seen across an inland lake.

items.synopsis: A group of scientists finds despite billions of dollars spent on the Murray Darling Basin Plan, many of the indicators used to measure whether the environment is receiving enough water have been getting worse.

title.children: As new Murray Darling Basin rules get debated, scientists say there's a clear path to improving the rivers' health

image.altText: Prince William, Kate, Princess of Wales, Prince Harry, and Meghan at the Queen's funeral.

items.synopsis: The plans for her death were meticulous. Her lavish funeral had a code name. But when the kingdom's second Elizabethan era drew to a close, everyone suddenly seemed to be a little caught off-guard.

title.children: 'I was welcome at Balmoral … but without her': How family tensions gripped the Queen's final hours

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Catherine King has pledged airfares will soon come down, saying Qatar Airways is "not the only airline that adds to competition".

title.children: Catherine King says airfares 'will come down' as other airlines increase capacity

image.altText: Vivienne Mitchell's face and upper body is superimposed over a picture of razors that has a price tag of $43

items.synopsis: Backlash against Coles and Woolworths is swirling on social media as the supermarket giants record large profits amid a cost of living crisis. But one expert says the anger, and calls for a boycott, are unlikely to have a lasting effect.

title.children: How one Australian's 'sheer disbelief' at the rising cost of groceries reached 1.7 million shoppers

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison has warned that his successor should not be "too keen" to accept an invitation to China, as Anthony Albanese prepares to visit Beijing within months.

title.children: Scott Morrison says Anthony Albanese shouldn't rush to visit Bejiing this year

image.altText: An aerial view of flooded parts of Echuca.

items.synopsis: A northern Victorian council has approved 16 townhouses to be built on land that was significantly flooded in the Murray River town of Echuca during last year's flood.

title.children: 'Absolutely crazy': Developer gets approval to build 16 homes on site of Echuca 'inland sea'

image.altText: Peter speaks outside court and gestures with his right hand as protesters stand behind him.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Former Trump adviser convicted of contempt of congress. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has pushed back against concerns raised by Scott Morrison over the prime minister's upcoming visit to China. Anthony Albanese announced yesterday that he would visit Beijing in November, the first Australian prime minister to do so since Malcolm Turnbull in 2016. Earlier this week, Scott Morrison warned the government's "keenness" to restore relations with China would be interpreted in Beijing as Australia being "concessional and acquiescent". Peter Dutton told RN Breakfast it's appropriate for the prime minister to go to China. "It's appropriate for the prime minister to go because he's got an invitation and he's also got a list of issue to raise," Dutton said. "He obviously believes he can get some way in relation to the relief around the tariffs which have been imposed, human rights issues obviously."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dutton pushes back against Morrison's comments over PM's visit to China

children.content: has pushed back against concerns raised by Scott Morrison over the prime minister's upcoming visit to China.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North Korea has launched a new tactical nuclear attack submarine, state media has reported. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un attended the submarine-launching ceremony, news agency KCNA said. "The submarine-launching ceremony heralded the beginning of a new chapter for bolstering up the naval force of the DPRK," KCNA said, using the initials of the North's official name, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Korea launches new tactical nuclear attack submarine

props.alt: Kim Jong Un assesses a huge submarine.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prince Harry has paid tribute to the late Queen Elizabeth as he returned to Britain to attend an awards ceremony a day before the first anniversary of his grandmother's death. "As you know, I was unable to attend the awards last year as my grandmother passed away," he said in a speech at the annual ceremony staged in London by WellChild, a charity supporting children suffering from serious illnesses, for which he is a patron. "As you also probably know, she would have been the first person to insist that I still come to be with you all instead of going to her and that's precisely why I know exactly one year on that she is looking down on all of us tonight, happy we're together continuing to spotlight such an incredible community," he said. Queen Elizabeth died on September 8, 2022 at her Scottish home, Balmoral Castle. My colleagues Lucia Stein and Rebecca Armitage have the inside story of the Queen's last day — and how it set up the reign of King Charles, at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prince Harry back in Britain on anniversary of queen's death

featuredLink.title: 'I was welcome at Balmoral … but without her': How family tensions gripped the Queen's final hours

props.alt: Prince Harry smiles at the event.

image.altText: Empty streets in a rural town

items.synopsis: The tight-knit community of Kellerberrin faces a long road to recovery after a father was shot dead by another well-known local resident, who later turned the weapon on himself following a manhunt and police stand-off that forced the town into lockdown.

title.children: 'Everyone knows everyone': Small town reeling after gunman kills local father before turning weapon on himself

image.altText: Danny Masterson wears a face mask looking straight ahead in front of an orange background.

items.synopsis: A US judge sentences That ’70s Show star Danny Masterson to 30 years to life in prison for the rapes of two women two decades ago.

title.children: That '70s Show actor Danny Masterson jailed for 30 years to life for raping two women

image.altText: A satellite image showing Australia, New Zealand and an enormous mushroom cloud from a volcanic eruption in the Pacific ocean

items.synopsis: In January 2022, a mega explosion from the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano generated a coast-battering tsunami and vivid sunsets. Now we know the extent of the eruption's devastation below the waves.

title.children: 'Removed all life': Beneath the waves, Tongan volcano's eruption laid waste to the sea floor

image.altText: Plastic two litres of Coles milk in the dairy cabinet.

items.synopsis: Supermarket giant Coles is pushing to buy two milk factories, but Australian dairy farmers say it will give the retailer too much control over farm gate milk prices.

title.children: Farmers call on ACCC to block Coles milk factory deal amid 'bargaining power' fears

image.altText: A man stands looking at a pile of rubble and bricks that has crashed down

items.synopsis: Items set to be used at a young couple's wedding are lost when a tree destroyed their garage as Sydney is hit by a night of wind damage.

title.children: Wild winds lash Sydney, battering homes and blowing off roofs

image.altText: People wearing face masks try out the latest iPhone handsets at an Apple Store in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Wall Street finished lower overnight as China's ban on iPhones saw investors nervous about what it could mean for other tech stocks, while ASIC is suing AustralianSuper for allegedly failing to address multiple superannuation accounts. Follow live.

title.children: China's iPhone ban sends Apple and Wall Street lower, ASIC sues AustralianSuper, ASX set for modest gain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Telstra has issued a short release on the ASX confirming that it's in talks to purchase Melbourne-based cloud consultant Versent. It follows reporting in the Australian Financial Review earlier this week, which mentioned the deal is expected to be worth around $400 million. Telstra has confirmed they are in talks about a potential purchase of the company, but it is still in its early stages. "Telstra confirms it is participating in the process," the statement read. "References to the value of the offer are speculative. "There is no certainty a transaction involving Telstra will eventuate, should a transaction be finalised Telstra will update the market accordingly."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telstra confirms it's in talks to purchase cloud consultant Versent

children.content: has issued a short release on the ASX confirming that it's in talks to purchase Melbourne-based cloud consultant

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you didn't see it yesterday, Philip Lowe has gone out fighting in his final speech as Reserve Bank governor, warning that Australia's living standards are at risk without productivity reform. And on the way out, he's taken a swipe at the media over the reporting of his now infamous signal that interest rates would stay near zero until 2024. Meanwhile, corporate regulator ASIC is suing AustralianSuper alleging it failed to merge multiple member accounts and continued to charge multiple fees and insurance premiums. You can listen to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan's take on the last 24 hours in the business world here, or below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 🎧 RBA governor Philip Lowe takes aim at productivity and the media in final speech

last 24 hours in the business world here

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AustralianSuper has responded to the news this morning that ASIC has launched legal action against the superannuation fund, alleging it had failed to identify and combine multiple accounts. Here's the full statement from a spokesperson: "AustralianSuper regrets that its processes to identify and combine multiple accounts did not cover all  instances of multiple member accounts. "This should not have happened, and we apologise unreservedly to members. " AustralianSuper self-reported this issue and has fully cooperated with ASIC and APRA on this matter  and, separately, with ASIC for its 2022 industry review of the management of multiple member accounts. "AustralianSuper implemented a member remediation program for this matter earlier this year, which is  now substantially complete. "Having identified this issue, we have strengthened our processes to identify and combine multiple  accounts and remain committed to minimising these for members. "AustralianSuper will continue to work with ASIC to bring these proceedings to a resolution."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AustralianSuper responds to ASIC's legal action, says it self-reported the issue

image.altText: Russia's President Vladimir Putin, India's PM Narendra Modi and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

items.synopsis: When the G20 began in 2008 against a backdrop of a global economic crisis, nations came together to fix problems both internationally and at home. Fifteen years later, the event is struggling to even get a full list of attendees.

title.children: Demolished slums, new roads, and animal control: India is going all out for G20, but is it still relevant?

image.altText: A composite picture of Qatar Airways and Qantas airliners on the tarmac.

items.synopsis: A decision announced in July to deny Qatar Airways more flights to major Australian cities has resulted in accusations of protectionism for Qantas, criticism from the private sector and ACCC, and a parliamentary inquiry. This is how it all unfolded.

title.children: How a government decision over flight routes saw Qantas grilled and parliament launch an inquiry

image.altText: Man in red jacket with light on his head

items.synopsis: The operation to rescue the experienced US cave researcher from the depths of southern Türkiye's Taurus Mountains involves teams from Bulgaria, Croatia, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Türkiye.

title.children: Race to save injured explorer 1,000 metres inside cave in Türkiye

image.altText: China 6G

items.synopsis: Chinese state media has pointed to Huawei's new smartphone as evidence the United States' attempts to curtail China's microchip development are failing. So how significant is the tech in the new phone and what does it mean for the "chip wars"?

title.children: Huawei launched a new phone without fanfare last week. But the technology it uses has sparked intense debate

image.altText: A man in a white shirt looks into a food delivery bag

items.synopsis: An analysis of data from China's second largest food delivery service shows that adding a "green nudge" could eliminate more than 3 million tonnes of single-use plastic.

title.children: One tiny change to food delivery apps could eliminate millions of tonnes of plastic waste

image.altText: Catherine King standing speaking wearing a bright red blazer.

items.synopsis: Could her resurrection of the 2020 strip search incident be one way of seeking to neutralise an issue that has been otherwise debated – to the government's detriment – in terms of limiting competition?

title.children: Catherine King's baffling week leaves more questions than answers on Qatar decision

image.altText: Naomi Bowden

items.synopsis: Through tears Naomi Bowden tells a NSW inquiry into birth trauma how distressing it was to have police take her stillborn daughter and put her in an ice box in front of her.

title.children: Naomi speaks up about the 'disrespectful' treatment she received after her baby was stillborn

image.altText: A Wallabies player gestures with his hand during a Test against France.

items.synopsis: Winless so far this year, Eddie Jones makes a surprise selection in his Wallabies starting XV ahead of their Rugby World Cup match against Georgia at Stade de France.

title.children: Jones pulls selection shock as 'F1' Wallabies prepare for Rugby World Cup opener

image.altText: A surveillance camera is silhouetted behind a Chinese national flag in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Proposed changes to a Chinese public security law to criminalise comments, clothing or symbols that "undermine the spirit" or "harm the feelings" of the country trigger the concern of legal experts, who say the amendments could be used arbitrarily.

title.children: China's draft law banning 'harming the feelings' of the country sparks backlash

image.altText: Myanmar Now photojournalist Sai Zaw Thaike.

items.synopsis: A court in Myanmar sentences a photojournalist for an underground news agency to 20 years in prison with hard labour for his coverage of a deadly cyclone's aftermath.

title.children: Myanmar photojournalist jailed for 20 years over cyclone aftermath reporting

image.altText: Qatar Airways and Qantas planes on tarmac in Perth.

items.synopsis: This week delivered a brutal lesson in how a political perception problem can suddenly become a spectacular, fridge-melting conflagration, write Annabel Crabb and Brett Worthington.

title.children: At some point, love for Qantas died. What was the final straw?

image.altText: An Australian male batter prepares to hit the ball in an ODI against South Africa.

items.synopsis: Marnus Labuschagne comes to Australia's rescue in the role of concussion substitute, lifting his side to a three-wicket win over South Africa in the first ODI at Bloemfontein.

title.children: Concussion sub Labuschagne guides Australia to ODI win over South Africa

image.altText: German defence officials climb on a Boxer army vehicle in australia

items.synopsis: Barely two months ago, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced a $1 billion Defence deal with Germany while visiting Berlin. But after that country missed out on a reciprocal contract, the relationship is now looking unlikely.

title.children: Growing doubts about German commitment to $1b Australian Army export deal

image.altText: An aerial photo showing the RACV resort near the coastline.

items.synopsis: A coastal council is calling on the Victorian government to develop policies that provide certainty for seaside communities amid concerns erosion and rising sea levels will leave them unrecognisable.

title.children: Victorian council calls for state support to protect coastal communities from climate change

image.altText: a man ina lab coat leaning on a large furnace

items.synopsis: A furnace that reaches 3,000 degrees Celsius is helping scientists make parts for hypersonic jets and test components for space travel and defence.

title.children: This furnace is the hottest in the southern hemisphere, and it's used to make hypersonic jets

image.altText: A group of Collingwood AFL players embrace and celebrate after a goal.

items.synopsis: Collingwood has survived a late Melbourne charge to win a tense qualifying final by seven points in front of 92,000 fans at the MCG.

title.children: Collingwood holds on to win epic qualifying final over Melbourne

image.altText: The Webb Ellis Cup is held up in the air.

items.synopsis: The Wallabies are ranked ninth in the world ahead of the 2023 Rugby World Cup, but coach Eddie Jones still thinks they can win. Here's everything you need to know about the tournament in France.

title.children: Who the Wallabies are up against at the Rugby World Cup 2023

image.altText: An AFL player lies on a stretcher and is carted off with support staff around him.

items.synopsis: Collingwood may not be able to count on Brayden Maynard for the rest of the finals, after the defender is put on report for a collision that left Melbourne's Angus Brayshaw stretchered off the ground with concussion.

title.children: Maynard says sickening collision with Brayshaw was a 'footy act'

image.altText: Lowe is wearing a blue suit, looking straight into camera, sitting at a desk.

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe says we could manage inflation better, and floated ideas on how to do that, while addressing "vitriol" directed his way, in final speech.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe warns about future inflation, criticises 'personal attacks', in final speech

image.altText: Belinda and Kobee Huddy smile for a selfie.

items.synopsis: Early one May morning in 2019, 20-year-old Kobee Huddy was desperate for help. He called a mental health service for advice. Less than four hours later he would be dead – shot by police.

title.children: Did Kobee's cry for help kill him? How a knife-wielding mentally ill young man was fatally shot by police

image.altText: Sgt Richard Monei sits at table with police hat next to him

items.synopsis: Richard Monaei joined the Queensland Police Service when he was 18. He's now an advocate so other First Nations people don't suffer as he did.

title.children: Racism forced Richard out of Queensland Police. He says a newly announced review is 'long overdue'

image.altText: The website for eHarmony, which has a picture of a smiling blonde, white woman

items.synopsis: eHarmony is hit with a lawsuit by the consumer watchdog, alleging the dating site breached Australian consumer law by making misleading statements about the pricing, renewal and cancellation of its memberships.

title.children: Nishan hasn't used eHarmony for 20 months but hasn't been able to remove himself from its billing cycle
